description.narrative: The ATSEA-2 is designed to enhance sustainable development of the Arafura-Timor Seas region to protect biodiversity and improve the quality of life of its inhabitants through conservation and sustainable management of marine-coastal ecosystems.
seat of a first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: ATSEA- 2 Regional Office based in Tuna Research Center, facilities under Ministry of Marine and Fisheries Affair (MMAF). Coordination within 3 Countries under the ATSEA-2 project will lead from this office

As this project is regional in context, the selection of sites is rooted in the transboundary dimension of the priority environmental concerns concluded in the TDA. Some of the planned regional level activities include implementing EAFM on the scale of a Large Marine Ecosystem (LME), reducing IUU fi

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: 1. Regional governance mechanism 2. National Inter-Ministerial Committees (NIMCs) 3. SAP implementation finance secured by governments and development partners 4. Number of local regulations issued to support implementation of NAP that reflect regional harmonization of national and subnational policies 5. Knowledge transferred from capacitated trainers to resource beneficiaries 6. Regional climate change predictive capacity strengthened 7. 10. Proportion of countries that are implementing specific measures from the SAP (i.e. adopted national policies, laws, budgeted plans) 8. Number of management plans and appropriate measures implemented for rebuilding or protecting fish stocks including alternative management approaches 9. Number of targeted communities of fishers have adopted an ecosystem approach to fisheries management 10. Reduced fishing pressure 11. Improved use of fish gear/techniques 12. 15. Strengthened oil spill oil response systems and capacities 13. Protected area management effectiveness score 14. Number of threatened species under enhanced protection 15. Adoption and implementation of ICM plans and reforms to protect coastal zones in LMEs – Number of beneficiary countries adopting and applying ICM within ATS region 16. Number of women and men supported with alternative likelihoods that contribute to improved management of natural resources and increased resilience of their local communities with respect to the impacts of climate change 17. Mechanism in place to produce a monitoring report on stress reduction measures 18. Dissemination of project results and ATS information

comment.narrative: 1. Informal cooperation under ATSEF, and conceptualization of ATS governance mechanism outlined in Ministerial Declaration 2. NIMCs loosely formed, with no clear mandate for ATS priority concerns 3. No SAP implementation finance secured by governments and development partners 4. Priority actions in the NAPs are not mainstreamed in national and local policy and programming frameworks 5. Limited local knowledge on integrated approaches 6. There are no coordinated regional climate change assessment efforts addressing regional coastal and marine concerns in the ATS region 7. No countries that are implementing specific measures from the SAP 8. No management plans and appropriate measures implemented for rebuilding or protecting fish stocks including alternative management approaches 9. Aru, Indonesia: Approx. 775 registered fishing vessels in Aru operating in the red snapper and shrimp fisheries (combined). 10. South Fly, PNG: 2 tons per year dried fish maw (bladder) produced. 11. Aru, Indonesia: Approx. 775 registered fishing vessels in Aru operating in the shrimp and red snapper fisheries; 775 vessels (<30 GT) which do not have VMS; 1400 vessels using gillnet gear. 12. Merauke, Indonesia: Approx. 500 registered fishing vessels operating in the barramundi fishery in Merauke. 13. South Coast, Timor-Leste: Approx. 150 registered vessels in the south coast municipalities. 14. South Fly, PNG: Approx. 2700 households involved in small-scale fishing 15. Oil and gas development is expanding in the ATS region, but local communities lack awareness and capacity to respond to marine pollution incidents 16. Indonesia: Southeast Aru MPA METT: 39 17. Timor-Leste: NKS NP METT: 24 18. No threatened species under enhanced protection 19. No coastal areas are currently under ICM; Timor-Leste is currently preparing ICM plans with support of PEMSEA 20. None yet women and men supported with alternative likelihoods that contribute to improved management of natural resources and increased re

Component 1 Regional and National Governance for LME Management 1. Finalization of the regional governance model, including TOR and guidelines for the Stakeholder Partnership Forum (SPF). 2. Initiation of the ATS Transboundary Diagnostic Analysis (TDA) update. The report will be finalized in 2022. 3. Completion of the Climate Change (CC) Vulnerability Assessment Report. 4. Development of the Gender Equity and Social Inclusion (GESI) and assessment of Social and Environmental Safeguards (SES).
Component 2. Improving LME Carrying Capacity 1. Finalization of the regional thematic assessment reports related to climate change, IUU fishing, marine pollution, and habitat and biodiversity conservation. 2. Progress made on the development of EAFM plan. 3. Organization of the webinars and workshops in support of the different thematic studies.
Component 3 Knowledge Management 1. Launched an enhanced website and social media platforms supported by more regular postings. 2. Publications of the Project Annual Report, quarterly newsletters, press releases, and short videos on the project results and campaign. 3. Participation and dissemination of the project results in relevant virtual events.

Building on the experiences from 2020, particularly on the changes and challenges brought about by the global pandemic, the ATSEA-2 project has demonstrated better adaptive management in the year 2021 with majority of its regional target activities and outputs completed.
Under Component 1 on Regional and National Governance for LME Management, bulk of the efforts were accorded to the consultation process for the ATS regional governance mechanism. Recognizing the need to build country ownership and to facilitate better consensus-building, the original work plan for finalization of the regional governance model, including TOR and guidelines for the Stakeholder Partnership Forum (SPF), was recalibrated to allow for wider and deeper engagement of stakeholders in all four ATS countries. Thus, building on the regional governance assessment report, further national consultations have been completed with initial results to be presented at the 3rd RSC meeting in December 2021. Updating of the ATS Transboundary Diagnostic Analysis (TDA) has been initiated in November and will run up to November of 2022. As for climate change targets, the final Climate Change (CC) Vulnerability Assessment Report together with a Decision-making guidance toolkit has been completed, and shared through a Climate Change workshop. The toolkit has also been applied in the development of case study on impact of CC to fisheries in selected sites. Surveys and reports related to Gender Equity and Social Inclusion (GESI) and Social and Environmental Safeguards (SES) have also been completed.
Component 2 on Improving LME Carrying Capacity has also shown significant progress with the completion of all regional thematic assessment reports related to climate change, IUU fishing, marine pollution, and habitat and biodiversity conservation. While the development of EAFM plan would require further extension to secure more primary data, though alternative platforms such as online surveys, virtual FGDs of Advisory Forums, and deployment of enumerators have been carried out to address some of the limitations posed by COVID. The initial target of using LIPI’s research vessel was also cancelled due to COVID restrictions as well as organizational changes. LIPI and ATSEA-2, however, agreed to explore other technical collaboration in support of fisheries data gathering and management. Several webinars and workshops in support of the different thematic studies have also been conducted. As Component 2 requires several field activities that were affected by COVID restrictions, target regional exchange visits had to be postponed and moved to 2022 (i.e., Rights-based management fisheries visit to Australia).
In terms of Knowledge Management under Component 3, the project is on track on all targets except for the cross-project visits that were also affected by COVID restrictions. In 2021, the project has launched an enhanced website and social media platforms supported by more regular postings. Numbers of viewers and subscribers to ATSEA pages have also steadily increased. Several publications such as the Annual Report, quarterly newsletters, press releases, videos, etc. have been completed, posted and/or disseminated to a wider audience. ATSEA-2 has also actively participated and co-organized several virtual forums or events.

1. Finalize recruitment process of regional project management personnel. 2. Organize and conduct RSC meeting in coordination with Timor-Leste as host. 3.Secure consultant to develop political and legal analysis of ATS region. 4.Conduct consultations for on political and legal analysis at NCUs or NPBs. 5.Secure consultant to develop TOR and guidelines for SPF. 6. Organize and conduct SPF back to back with RSC. 7. Consultant under no.3 to conduct regional institutional review in ATS and present initial result at RSC. 8. Consultant under no.3 to undertake assessment of political economy of regional in ATS region and present initial results to RSC. 9.Secure consultant on climate change to undertake regional review of climate change with national climate change professionals and present initial results to RSC. 10.Secure consultant on EAFM to collate baseline data and present initial EAFM plan at RSC. 11. Secure consultant on IUU fishing to update baseline estimates on IUU fishing in ATS and review national policies and legislation on IUU with initial result to be presented at RSC. 12. RPMU to participate in RPoA-IUU subregional committee meeting and coordination committee meeting. 13. Secure consultant on marine and land-based pollution to carry out assessment at regional and Indonesia pollution hotspots with initial result to be presented a RSC. 14. Secure consultant to undertake review and gap analysis resulting to a regional profile of ecosystem assets, connectivity and evaluation pressures, with initial assessment report to be presented at RSC. 15. Secure a consultant to design ATS MPA Network with initial draft to be presented or consulted at RSC. 16. Consultant under no.15 to develop regional plan of action for enhanced protection of marine turtles to be presented at RSC. 17. Coordinate cross-country visits if possible. 18. Secure consultant for project monitoring and evaluation and assist RPMU Policy and Resource-based Specialist in initial research and preparation of draft framework for ATS SAP Monitoring Mechanism. 19. Secure Communications Consultant to develop Stakeholder Engagement and Communications Plan for presentation at RSC. 20. Communicate project results and findings at RSC. 21. Develop and maintain contacts database. 22. Organize regional exchange activities if possible. 23. Develop, launch and regularly update ATSEA website. 24. Circulate e-newsletter via project social media sites. 25. Participate in various international and regional events and share ATSEA work and accomplishments.

In 2020, the project management has been completed on board, with special procedures and measures followed the COVID 19 protocols. The regional PMU start operating in Denpasar, Bali. The RSC meeting was conducted virtually in early Dec 2020, participated by project country members.

1. Recommendations and decisions on key ATSEA-2 initiatives, including Work Plan and Budget for 2022, reached at RSC Meeting 2022. 2. Design and action plan for the operationalization of Regional Governance Mechanism, including inputs from legal, administrative and financial assessment on operationalization of the mechanism approved. 3. SPF work plan 2022 implemented and reviewed during quarterly meetings. 4. Financial Landscape Assessment Report/Guidance Document published and disseminated. 5. GESI Action Plan implemented and results monitored and reported to RSC 2022 and as part of project M&E reporting. 6. Familiarization on Climate Change Adaptation (CCA) tools and use of CCA Decision-making Guidance Toolkit promoted through conduct of Regional trainings on CCA. 7. Updated ATS TDA Report. 8. Regional EAFM Plan endorsed by RSC 2022. 9. Updated IUUF baseline data compiled, shared and considered in TDA updating. 10. Updated Marine pollution assessment compiled and considered in TDA updating. 11. MPA Network Design endorsed by RSC and proposed roadmap considered in TDA and SAP updating. 12. ATS SAP Monitoring and Reporting System developed building on ToC, pilot tested, and adopted for future performance monitoring. 13. Project Finding and Outputs packaged through various media including ATSEA website and shared at key ATSEA meetings. 14. Engagement of key media groups in ATS region strengthened through fellowship program and selected events. 15. Updated Stakeholder Engagement and Communications Plan guiding the communication and outreach activities of ATSEA2.
